message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of reducing substances in urine suggests carbohydrate intolerance, which can be caused by a deficiency in enzymes involved in carbohydrate metabolism. Giving this patient apple juice, which is high in fructose, will cause an increase in the activity of hexokinase, which is involved in the metabolism of fructose. None of the other options are involved in fructose metabolism.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of reducing substances in the urine indicates a possible galactosemia, which is a deficiency in galactose metabolism. Giving apple juice to a healthy infant would lead to an increase in activity of the enzyme hexokinase, which is important in glucose metabolism. However, in a patient with galactosemia, giving apple juice would not have the same effect as the enzymes involved in galactose metabolism are deficient. Therefore, this question is asking for the enzyme that would be affected in a healthy infant, which is hexokinase.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of reducing substances in urine suggests a possible carbohydrate metabolism disorder. Giving apple juice to this patient will result in increased activity of Hexokinase due to the excess fructose present in apple juice, which will be metabolized via the hexokinase pathway. This is why apple juice is not recommended for infants with suspected carbohydrate metabolism disorders like galactosemia. Aldolase B is involved in fructose metabolism but is not relevant in this case. Galactokinase is involved in galactose metabolism and α-1,6-glucosidase is involved in glycogen metabolism, but neither are affected by fructose intake.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of reducing substances in the urine suggests galactosemia. Apple juice contains high levels of fructose, which can cause secondary hypoglycemia in patients with galactosemia due to inhibition of hexokinase activity. Therefore, giving apple juice to this patient will result in decreased activity of hexokinase.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The fact that the urinalysis shows 3+ reducing substances suggests that the patient has a deficiency in one of the enzymes involved in carbohydrate metabolism. Giving apple juice, which is high in fructose, could result in increased activity of hexokinase, the enzyme that helps metabolize fructose. Aldolase B deficiency leads to hereditary fructose intolerance, galactokinase deficiency leads to galactosemia, and α-1,6-glucosidase deficiency leads to glycogen storage disease type 3.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of reducing substances in the urine suggests a possible diagnosis of lactose intolerance. Compared to a healthy infant, giving this patient apple juice will result in increased activity of hexokinase, which is involved in the metabolism of fructose. None of the other options are involved in fructose metabolism.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of reducing substances in the urine suggests a possible carbohydrate metabolic disorder, specifically a deficiency in glycogen storage disease. Giving apple juice, which contains fructose, to a healthy infant would activate hexokinase, an enzyme involved in glucose metabolism. Therefore, giving apple juice to this patient would not lead to increased activity of any of the enzymes listed.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of reducing substances in the urine suggests the patient has a deficiency of a carbohydrate-metabolizing enzyme. Among the options, only Hexokinase is involved in carbohydrate metabolism, specifically the conversion of glucose to glucose-6-phosphate. Therefore, giving the patient apple juice (which contains high amounts of fructose) will lead to increased activity of Hexokinase.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of reducing substances in the urine suggests a possible diagnosis of galactosemia, which affects the activity of the enzyme galactose-1-phosphate uridylyltransferase. Giving the patient apple juice, which contains fructose, will result in increased activity of the enzyme hexokinase.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of reducing substances in the urine suggests a possible condition called galactosemia, which results in the inability to metabolize galactose. Giving the patient apple juice, which contains fructose, can lead to increased activity of Hexokinase, which can metabolize both glucose and fructose, but not galactose. None of the other options are directly related to the metabolism of galactose or fructose.
